Early Access Review

There are certain gameplay mechanics that are extremely annoying in this game.

1) The ghosts don't die instantly when you flash your torch light at them. They take a while to die. This gets really annoying when in later levels they are coming from multiple directions at the same time. It's not fun when you're toggling back and forth between the two ghosts.

2) Collect all letters to unlock a bonus level. Sounds like a good relaxation after your work? Nopes. Those bonus levels are exceptionally tough. When a game's tough above a threshold it doesn't feel fun anymore. It becomes a chore instead.

3) Die-restart mechanism + The â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ jumps = Let's say you keep jumping around different platforms and keep making progress in the level. You jump at some locations. Die, then figure out how to deal with it then try again. But the catch is that you need to start all over from the beginning again and go all the distance again. And all enemies are alive again. It's like groundhog day. There are no checkpoints in this game. Die-restart-die-restart-die-restart. It quickly gets annoying.

And a warning about the jumps. A lot of parts are just instincts - jumping the exact distance. No more no less. If you pressed shift (run key) throughout the jump then you overshoot and die. If you released it a little earlier you'll still fall on the edge and can fall down. If you released it at less than half the distance you'll fall before the ledge and die. The time to release it is too narrow. Combined with the game's die-restart mechanism these jumps become bad gameplay.

4) Lastly the drops. You get each drop in about 2-3 hours. There are a total of 4 drops (aka Trading cards)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, the game is okay.
It's a very simple game. You avoid spikes, jump onto moving platforms, jump off of blocks before they disappear, collect a key to open a door, etc. While doing all that, you also have a flashlight that you need to point at occasional ghosts that will try to kill you (they look pretty damn creepy).

The platforming is decent, however the camera is pretty irritating. First of all, to move the flashlight, you need to hold the mouse button down, as opposed to just moving it around, which would have been a lot better. If you're NOT holding the mouse button down and decide to change directions while walking, the camera is really janky and will jump around. It doesn't make the game harder in a good way, just a frustrating way. (EDIT: There actually is a way to toggle the other type of flashlight control by clicking the right mouse button. However, it isn't ever mentioned in the game, so it isn't very clear.) Despite that though, the game is pretty easy. I never really felt like there was much challenge, and it's quite short as well.

Overall, I like the aesthetic, but the gameplay isn't very engaging. It is in early access, so it's possible a few of these annoying mechanics will be fixed, but the level design and general gameplay can't really be mended. It's good that it's a cheap game, so perhaps you could pick it up if you like the look of it.

Early Access Review

Neat top-down platforming game involving a flash light as your weapon. You're tasked with running around in the dark looking for letters to create sigils while fending off ghosts that randomly come after you.

The good:
Cool concept
There's an interesting story built in
The story is told in audio while sifting through each level
Steam cards

The bad:
Jumping: Stop pressing forward and you sink like a rock
Jumping from one platform to the other gets really touchy after the first level
Ghosts seem to be stopped only by progessing into the leve, not by killing them with light

This isn't really a bad game, it just needs some touching up; namely the jumping aspect which, in it's current state, doesn't seem natural for a quasi-platformer. I personally can't get beyond this part as jumping seems to be a big part of solving puzzles in this game and it's just shoddy. I'll still recommend it, but won't pick it up again unless there's another update for the controls.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBetter than I expected.  In its current state, it is a short platformer that was more fun and not very frustrating.   The full controller support worked very well for controls with an xbox360 gamepad.  The right thumbstick points the flashlight, the left thumbstick moves (and flashlight automatically shines in direction you are moving), right-trigger runs, A jumps.  The game is mostly platforming, and thankfully not as much about timing jumps perfectly.  You can collect letters spread throughout the level, or just go fairly straight to level completion.  There are hidden platforms that show up only when you are right in front of them, buttons to press, spring jumps, and moving platforms.  Occasionally there are ghosts that are defeated by pointing the flashlight at them.  In a few places it was a little challenging to fight off a horde of ghosts, but the best trick is to backtrack a little and just shine the flashlight at them all at once.  I beat all 5 levels in world 0, and as far as I can tell there is no more worlds (at the time of this review).  This was a pleasant surprise (3/5 stars).

I know this isn't every early access game but a lot are like this. This game from the looks of it was either rushed, not cared about enough, or by inexperienced devise. First of all I noticed the controls for the torch, these are horrible you can either not do anything and it will snap to the direction you are facing which leads to very disorientating gameplay ad there is no smooth animation for the snap lock and leaves the player felling more or less dizzy, or you can hold the left mouse button the whole time to control the torch which is annoying while trying to do platforming but is much easier then the snap control. This was very annoying through he whole game as you do have to use the torch as a weapon and making it a prime function without taking much care for smooth animation is not done well. While trying to find an option to maybe have it as a consonant on the mouse control I found myself exiting the level which made me instantly dislike this game. First of all there was no are you sure you want to exit the level, second no indication what so ever through the game did it say if you want to exit the level press ESC, this may not seem like that big of a deal and it wouldn't be in any other situation but in mine I was near the end of the level with all the collectibles and I had exited and was forced to play the level again but this time I ha dlost interest in collecting the letters. Another issue I have is that there are no options, none what so ever, except when you boot up the game it asks what graphics you would like windowed yes or no and resolution, for the very basic of settings these are there is no way to change them in game. One other thing that really bugged me about this game is the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing narrator, jeez can you come up with some different lines, every single level has the narrator saying the same thing over and over again, it's like a broken record, and I'm not kidding at the start of every level there is the same cut scene of the narrator saying some bull and during every level he says the same thing, and at the end of every level there is another cut scene. Not to be discouraging the narrator has a nice voice but maybe get him a few more then 3 things to say. Now one thing that really bugged me about the game play was that every time you die you go all the way top the start of the level usually this would be OK, it gives consequence to the players death but it is so easy to die in this game from the odd camera angle and the (let' face it) clichÃ© platforming with no real unique aspect means you have to start the level again and when this happens you loose all of your collectibles. This is the most frustrating part because even though the platforming is hard simply because of other issue and not the way it is designed, a big portion of the game comes froms getting the collectibles and after dying a few time to some random issue I quickly lost interest in getting the collectibles which unlock additional levels, which I could not bring my self to even collect the letter to play because I found myself wanting to stop playing this game instantly. Another aspect of the game I didn't enjoy was the enemy if you can even call them that, there are two enemy's, white slug things that slowly move towards you and little white sperm things that move quickly towards you, for a game with the subtitle 'A game to fight inner demons' I did not find myself fighting any inner demons the most I got was having a good laugh at the ridiculous design of an 'inner demon' and the variation of these inner demons (the small sperm things) do not come in till the 4th level which is the second last level in the game. Which brings me to my next point the length of this game is ridiculous it is less then an hour I'm sure if you went through all the levels getting the collectibles it be a bit longer but no more then 2 hours it is ridiculous, if you are going to make a game with this kind of game play and non existent story telling at least make it long enough so people get their moneys worth. Another aspect I found odd was music or the lack of, the first time I heard music was in the last stage of the game and there was no epicness to it like in dark souls where music would only play during boss battles but dark souls made the iteration of music mean something, it made the player feel like they were doing something epic not bloody doing mundane platforming.

So if you are looking to buy this game I wouldn't bother the $1 price it is definitely not worth it in the sate that it is in now.
